title: Can we just agree it's more exciting when a champ is weak on release?
body:
When Bard gets buffed enough and learned enough to get picked in LCS, everyone _cheers._ It's an underdog story. People play him a bit on release, stop playing him when he sucks, and have fun learning his ins-and-outs without feeling like he's a crutch. It's not as good as a perfect balance situation ({{champion:161}} ) but it's not awful.

Meanwhile, Ekko.

Bard gets buffed twice, and people cheer to see this new champion played professionally.

Because again, he's been out for _4 days_ .

Have you even played ten games against him?  How many in the same lane?

If you've played 10 games since Ekko came out, you have inevitably played 10 games with an Ekko. Yes, seriously.

Preach it! I feel like this is going to have the reverse Yasuo effect. He'll appear OP on release, and he'll be nerfed because of all the QQing all over the boards. Then we'll learn to play against him, and his winrate will drop to elise levels.

Not quite the same thing. Ekko has _options._ Even when he does poorly in lane (ie. when you get Ekko mirrors) he can still make an impact because his ult can save him from almost any misplay and his W can stun the entire enemy team. His Q also applies a crazy slow, his W passive lets him cherrypick kills without building items, and his regular passive means he can kite forever without getting caught.

This is intentional, from what I understand - his kit is loaded so that he has a lot of opportunities to outplay people and make a difference without damage. The thing is that he _still has a stupid amount of damage_ because his scaling is outrageously high. He'll get nerfed, people will stop building him full AP (or they'll start playing him safer), and he'll still have ways to survive because everything on his kit has a secondary purpose other than damage.

Yasuo doesn't have that.

That's one thing that has really pissed me off, the fact that every new champion now has to have 50 things shoved into each ability (and passive) besides the ability itself. Especially the auto attack stacks that every other new champion gets.

Yasuo doesn't, no. Also unlike Yasuo, everything in his kit is predictable and avoidable. He lacks much utility (Or damage, though most of his damage comes from lichbane+Luden's anyhow) against an enemy team that's playing smart against him, and people will begin to learn to do that as time passes.

Also, the luden's nerfs on PBE will probably have a strong effect on him and his laning ability. He's extremely dependent on his item build, as the extra scalings he get from it are required to give him some level of reliable strength.
You made that sound like Luden's is being nerf on the PBE because of Ekko.
I don't believe that's the case, but it will have a noteworthy effect on him none the less.

Yeah, I think a more support style mid laner who when he does well to combo everything well _can_ assassinate people fits ekko as opposed to the current assassin mid laner who also has tons of cc and escapability.

According to champion.gg, his average win rate is 44.73%. 96.12% of Ekko players are in their 1st - 5th ranked games as him. 3.03% are in their 5th - 15th. The average win rate of Ekko players in their 1st - 5th games is 44.53%. The average win rate of Ekko players in their 5th - 15th games is 59.89%. I can't tell whether the winrates given for higher games played are valid or if there just aren't enough analyzed games for champion.gg to actually give a number different from the average. Based on the current data, however, Ekko appears to be OP.
I'm just surprised it's different from 50.00% (because there's one on each team).

I also don't think he is OP, I just think Riot was aiming for a very different play style, because right now Ekko isn't a "utility assassin" like they wanted, he is a "kill you in a second assassin" like Zed or LB, which is what they said they didn't want. I just want him to feel more unique (I really want Riot to embrace his utility based design), less like it is all about getting Luden's and Lich bane so you can half-life the ADC. We have plenty of assassins that blow people up, and Ekko was supposed to be to assassins like Varus or Ashe are to ADCs, not *another* instagib assassin.

I think reducing his numbers is likely the best way to get him away from insta-gib and towards utility.  Basically, unless you get rid of his insta-gib potential there is no real reason not to go for the insta-gibbing.  Utility is fine, but a dead ADC is generally better than a few slows.
He really doesn't instagib anyone, though, unless he's _incredibly_ fed or you walk into his ult.
He doesn't need to be fed, he just needs to get to mid-late game and his E-Q-AA combo will one shot a squishy.

Even assuming he gets off the passive proc, that combo does only .2 AP or so more than leblanc's Q-W combo. And considering that's all the damage in his kit aside from his ult, whereas leblanc has much more reliable extra damage tied to her E and R, he really can't burst half as well as she can without someone walking over his time ghost.

You aren't factoring in Lich bane (which you would be foolish not to build on him), while also forgetting his execute proc, which in most cases is enough to insta-kill a squishy that is at or below the 30% HP threshold later in the game when combined with the Lich bane proc you get from casting Q. 

He gets ~655+200% AD+170% AP+2 Lich bane procs and (usually) a Luden's proc as well as ~16% Missing health. 

Leblanc's Q-W combo deals 555+140% AP, and only when she uses E does she actually equal Ekko's E-Q-AA in terms of raw damage. E is also far from reliable, since it is both a skillshot and a tether.

I didn't mention items because they're available to everyone, lichbane isn't an innate part of his kit and leblanc doesn't build it because other things work better on her. The reason she doesn't build it, I believe, is actually simply that she deos enough damage without it, and scales better off of additional AP than adding an extra AP scaling to her kit. Ekko's damage is quite lacking for an assassin without that extra scaling, which is a large part of the reason he buys it.

That said, I did forget about the W passive. My bad. I'm fairly certain still that all things being equal, leblanc's reliable damage (Q+W+R, we'll leave E out since as you said, it's a skillshot and therefore unreliable) far outshines Ekko's. Keep in mind the Q-W combo I originally mentioned is only a fraction of the normal leblanc kill combo, and the ekko combo we're comparing it too is all of his damage save an extremely situational ultimate. I have to admit, though, his burst is rather insane if he does land the ultimate.

I'm copying what I typed from another thread that was similar. :)

It's actually incredibly beneficial for balance purposes and for publicity's sake to release champions that are stronger than they should be. Releasing a champion that is too strong isn't a very bad thing, but releasing a champion that is too weak can be an incredibly bad thing. The bad that comes from releasing an underpowered champion is greater than the bad of a champion that is perceived as strong on release, and here's why.

* **Balance** 

When a champion is first released, nobody knows how to play him, and nobody knows how to play against him. This means that there is hardly any useful data for the balance team; without stable, consistent data, making balance changes is tricky. In order to know what to balance, people need to learn how to play the champion. What champions do people try to learn to play? The ones that are powerful. After people learn how to play these champions, they can use the statistics and truly say, "Okay, now that we have data from people who are actually learning this champion, we can tune him back a bit and make him balanced."

In short, Rito gets balance data faster if they're OP, because people will learn the champion, and the balance team will be able to know not just that the champion needs a nerf, but WHERE to nerf the champion. In the case of Ekko, is his shield *really* the problem, or is it his ultimate damage? Or could it even be his passive? Right now, the numbers are all over the place because he was *just* released. After a while, they'll know what's consistently strong and be able to fix it.

Releasing a champion that's underpowered on release is a nightmare for balance purposes. People play the champion, realise he's weak, and then **stop playing the champion altogether.** This is very very bad for balance purposes, because now the needed data is non-existent. The balance team can kind of guess what the problem is in an underpowered champion and try to buff it, but it may not even be the right thing to buff. Furthermore, it often leads to **overcompensation -** an underpowered champion gets buffed to the point where he's now OVERpowered. 

Of course, it won't SEEM overpowered, because since people refused to learn the champ on release, now nobody knows the potential of the champion, and the data once again becomes scattered as players begin learning the champion for what we can consider the first time. Now we're essentially back to square one, and the balance team has to wait even *longer* so they can get more useful data to know what to change to balance the champion out.

* **Publicity**

Did you read Harry Potter? What made you want to read the second book? Obviously, the first book was good. What if people told you the second book wasn't quite as good as the first book? Would you still read the second? Of course you would, because the first was so good, you'll at least give the second a chance. You'll know it's not quite there, but you're already into the series now.

Imagine if Harry Potter's first book was incredibly dull and boring. You hated it. Then somebody came up and told you that the second book was better than the first. Would you believe them? Would you really want to try that second volume after thinking the first book was terrible? Even if the second book *was* better, you'd hesitate to try to read it until it appeared on the NY Time's Best Seller list.

Champions work in similar ways. If a champion is really weak on release, you'd get a bad taste in your mouth for that champion. Even if a buff came around for that champion, would you look at yourself thinking, "Boy, I'm super excited to try him now!" Probably not. Not until LCS picked him up, at least. He'd always seem weak in your eyes until somebody else showed you the buffs were okay.

However, if you nerf a champion that was strong on release, people will have already learned the champion and will be sitting, reading the patch notes, thinking, "Okay, so Ekko's ult ratio is now 0.9 instead of 1.3. That's not so bad. He'll be fine. I still enjoy the champion and I'll still play him." 

And that's precisely why I do not mind having a champion on the strong side on release. While frustrating sometimes, and maybe not as "exciting" or having the underdog mindset, it ultimately is a rather smart thing to do from a big picture perspective.

I agree.  I'd rather champs come out underpowered and then be slowly buffed until they're relevant rather than the other way around.

If you aren't terrible Ekko is really pretty mediocre.  You NEED to land both your ult and w to even compete with other champions, since without those your damage and utility are both incredibly bad.  His poke does support-tier damage if the second half doesn't hit, his w has a huge cooldown and delay and the shield only lasts for 2 seconds making its size largely irrelevant, the e is on a significant cooldown for a dash and has awful damage and scaling, and the ult is massively underpowered if the damage doesn't land.  Ekko's ability to burst people down is entirely dependent on them standing where he was standing 4 seconds ago, and his utility is heavily dependent on fairly precisely predicting where both his opponents will be and he can be in 3 seconds.  If you're in Bronze where the average player is slightly less intelligent than a bot he's stupidly good, but when you don't just stand still while fighting him he brings almost nothing to fights.
I don't agree or disagree with most of what you said, but "If you're in Bronze where the average player is slightly less intelligent" is offensive. Not all Bronze players are stupid.
